title: Recidivism Watch: Bernie Sanders’s comparison of student loan interest rates to other loans
subtitle: We revisit a comparison that Sanders makes between student loan interest rates and other loan interest rates that aren't comparable, like auto loans and mortgages.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
We awarded Three Pinocchios to this apples-to-oranges comparison using cherry-picked numbers. Although student loan rates may reach 10 percent in some circumstances, there are much lower interest rates that are almost equal to the average 30-year mortgage rate. The comparison doesn’t work, since the two loans are so different. One major difference: You pay a lower interest rate on your home partly because you have a property at stake, unlike with a student loan.

We spotted a similar claim made in a post on Sanders’s Twitter account, comparing student loan interest rates to auto loans. His claim has been widely retweeted, but it’s equally mistaken.

Again, we’d like to remind the senator that auto loans are collateralized. This lack of collateral makes the student loan more risky than a loan for a home or a car. The current average auto loan rate is 2.59 percent for a used car for a 60-month term, 3.4 percent for 48-month term used car, and 3.3 percent for a new car with a 60-month term, according to Bankrate.com.

Student loans disbursed between 2006 and 2015 had interest rates from 3.4 percent to 8.5 percent. The highest federal student loan interest rates have been since 1988-89 was 12 percent, according to calculations by Mark Kantrowitz, who runs Cappex.com, a website that connects students with colleges and scholarships.

Under Sanders’s proposal, borrowers will be able to refinance or consolidate their federal student loans into interest rates of 2.3 to 3.1 percent, depending on the loan.

Since 2013, there has been a cap on federal student loan interest rates under the Bipartisan Student Loan Certainty Act. Undergraduate loans are capped at 8.25 percent, graduate loans at 9.25 percent and loans taken out by parents at 10.5 percent. While some Democrats heralded this law, others voted against it as it ties the student loan interest rates to 10-year Treasury bonds. Sanders joined Democrats opposing the law, saying rising interest rates would result in higher student loan rates.

The Fact Checker Recidivism Watch tracks politicians who repeat claims that we have previously found to be incorrect or false. These posts are short summaries of previous findings, with links to the original fact-check. We welcome reader suggestions.
